Document Name: Guidance On Monitoring and Reporting Requirements for Class II-D and II-R Injection Wells Underground Injection Control Program (PDF)
Description/Summary: In accordance with federal regulations 40 CFR Section 144.28 for rule-authorized wells and 40 CFR Section 146.23 for permitted injection wells, the owner or operator of a Class II-D or Class II-R injection well is required to submit an annual report summarizing the results of all monitoring activities.  In addition, owners or operators of permitted injection wells are required to submit a fluid analysis of the injectate.  These reports need to be submitted if the well is active, shut-in, or temporarily abandoned, and the current status of the well must be indicated on the report.

Document Name: Short-term Methods for Estimating the Chronic Toxicity of Effluents and Receiving Waters to West Coast Marine and Estuarine Organisms
Description/Summary: This EPA marine and estuarine toxicity test methods manual was developed for Pacific coastal waters for estimating the short-term chronic toxicity of effluents and receiving waters.  This methods manual describes short-term chgronic toxicity test methods (both static renewal and static nonrenewal) including laboratory operation and statistical data analysis approaches for eight test species:  the topsmelt, Atherinops affinis; the mysid, Holmesimysis costata; the sea urchin, Strongylocentrotus purpuratus and sand dollar Dendraster excentricus; the red abalone Haliotis rufescens; the bivalves Crassostrea gigas and mussel Mytilus spp.; and the giant kelp, Macrocystis pyrifera.

Description/Summary: Developed to help local governments identify opportunities to remove barriers, and revise and create codes, ordinances, and incentives for better water quality protection. Guides municipal staff through review of relevant local codes and ordinances, across multiple municipal departments and at the municipality, neighborhood, and site scales, to ensure that these codes work together to protect water quality goals. Two main goals: (1) help communities protect water quality by identifying ways to reduce the amount of stormwater flows and (2) educate stakeholders on policies and regulations that have water quality implications.

Document Name: Tier 2 and Tier 3 Public Notification Templates

These include the following violations: (1) failure to develop initial inventory for service line materials and/or make publicly accessible, (2) failure to report initial inventory to the state, and (3) failure to certify notification to consumers served by known or potential service line containing lead.

Document Name: Tier 1 Public Notification Templates following a Lead Action Level Exceedance
Description/Summary: The 2021 Lead and Copper Rule Revisions require water systems to issue a Tier 1 Public Notification (PN) when there is an exceedance of the lead action level no later than 24 hours after the systems learns of an exceedance. Water systems can use these templates to develop a Tier 1 PN for a lead action level exceedance.

Document Name: Toxicity Identification Evaluation: Characterization of Chronically Toxic Effluents, Phase I (PDF)
Description/Summary: This EPA Toxicity Identification Evaluation (TIE) Phase I guidance was developed to support National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit writers, NPDES dischargers and/or their consultant laboratories in conducting Phase I of short-term chronic freshwater aquatic toxicity TIEs to characterize the chemical/physical nature of the constituents in effluents which can cause aquatic chronic toxicity in receiving waters.

Document Name: Methods of Aquatic Toxicity Identification Evaluations – Phase I Toxicity Characterization Procedures; Second Edition (PDF)
Description/Summary: This EPA Toxicity Identification Evaluation (TIE) Phase I guidance, second edition, was developed to support National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit writers, NPDES dischargers and/or their consultant laboratories in conducting Phase I TIEs.  This 1991 TIE manual provides more details and more insight into the TIE Phase I techniques building on the prior 1988 first edition and describes the procedures for characterizing the physical/chemical nature of toxicants in acutely toxic effluent samples, with applications to other types of samples such as receiving water samples, sediment pore water or elutriate samples, and hazardous wastes.

Document Name: Methods for Aquatic Toxicity Identification Evaluations – Phase III Toxicity Confirmation Procedures for Samples Exhibiting Acute and Chronic Toxicity (PDF)
Description/Summary: This EPA Toxicity Identification Evaluation (TIE) Phase III guidance is the last in a series of procedural TIE documents to support National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit writers, NPDES dischargers and their consultant laboratories on conducting aquatic TIEs.  This TIE Phase Ill procedural manual used with the prior Phase I and II TIE documents provides guidance on confirming the cause of toxicity in industrial and municipal effluent discharges for both acute and short-term chronic toxicity to aquatic organisms in receiving waters.

Document Name: Methods for Aquatic Toxicity Identification Evaluations – Phase II Toxicity Identification Procedures for Samples Exhibiting Acute and Chronic Toxicity (PDF)
Description/Summary: This EPA Phase II aquatic Toxicity Identification Evaluation (TIE) acute and short-term chronic guidance document is the second of a three-phase series of documents that provide methods to characterize and identify the cause of toxicity in effluents. This TIE procedural document builds on the Phase I TIE document (characterized the possible sources of toxicity) by identifying the actual suspect toxicants.  This Phase II TIE guidance provides identification schemes for non-polar organic chemicals, ammonia, metals, chlorine, and surfactants that cause either acute or chronic toxicity.

Description/Summary: Describes how total maximum daily loads (TMDLs) and TMDL implementation plans can address hydrological factors that contribute to impairments by including green infrastructure. Summarizes two case studies to demonstrate principles discussed.

Description/Summary: Describes how green infrastructure approaches can be considered as part of an antidegradation review or use attainability analysis.

Document Name: Green Infrastructure Permitting and Enforcement Series: Supplement 1 - Consent Decrees that Include Green Infrastructure Provisions (PDF)
Description/Summary: Green infrastructure measures can be built into a consent decree as part of injunctive relief, as actions to be carried out and levels of control to be achieved. Document lists examples of existing consent decrees that include green infrastructure provisions along with links to the full documents.

Document Name: Green Infrastructure Permitting and Enforcement Series: Supplement 2 - Consent Decree Language Addressing Green for Grey Substitutions (PDF)
Description/Summary: On 12/22/2010 EPA and the Department of Justice announced a comprehensive CWA settlement with the Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District (NEORSD) to address the flow of untreated sewage into Cleveland waterways and Lake Erie. Settlement significantly advances use of large-scale green infrastructure projects to control wet weather sewer discharges by requiring NEORSD to invest at least $42 million in green infrastructure projects, and by providing the opportunity to propose larger uses of green infrastructure in exchange for reductions in the scope of traditional infrastructure projects. This supplement provides an excerpt from Appendix 4 of the consent decree documenting the settlement: “Requirements Applicable to the Proposals for Green for Gray Substitutions.”

Document Name: Green Infrastructure Permitting and Enforcement Series: Supplement 3 - Green Infrastructure Models & Calculators (PDF)
Description/Summary: Depending on their structure, modeling tools can be used to inform a variety of green infrastructure planning and design decisions: from setting a green infrastructure target for an entire watershed, to designing a green infrastructure practice for a particular site. Outputs that are particularly important in informing green infrastructure planning and design include runoff volume, runoff rate, pollutant loading, cost, and other environmental benefits. This supplement provides links to models that can be used to predict the performance and/or cost of green infrastructure approaches.

Document Name: Green Infrastructure Permitting and Enforcement Series: Supplement 4 - Green Infrastructure in Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDLs) (PDF)
Description/Summary: Where regulated or unregulated stormwater discharges are a major source of impairment, green infrastructure can play an important role in the development of Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDLs) and associated implementation plans. This supplement highlights two TMDLs that address flow, hydrology, and green infrastructure: the TMDL for the Olentangy River Watershed in Ohio, and the TMDL for the Barberry Creek Watershed in Maine. A summary of the two TMDLs is presented in Table 1, followed by excerpts of the language relating to green infrastructure.

Document Name: Pretreatment Streamlining Rule - Fact Sheet 8.0 - Slug Control Plans (EPA-833-F-07-004) (PDF)
Description/Summary: Describes slug control plan provisions of Pretreatment Streamlining Rule: "The Pretreatment Streamlining Rule provides flexibility for POTWs to determine how frequently to evaluate industrial users for the need for slug control plans, on the basis of local conditions after the initial assessment has been made. The rule also clarifies that an actual slug control plan is not the POTW’s only option for controlling facilities with a higher potential for slug discharges; instead, the POTW may choose to require that the significant industrial user take specific, preventative actions instead of requiring the development of a slug control plan. Those preventative actions and any slug control plan development requirements must be included in the SIU’s control mechanism."

Document Name: Pretreatment Streamlining Rule - Fact Sheet 4.0 - Equivalent Concentration-Based Limits for Flow-Based Standards (EPA-833-F-08-002) (PDF)
Description/Summary: As part of the 2005 Pretreatment Streamlining Rule, EPA created new flexibility for Control Authorities and Industrial Users by providing Control Authorities the discretion to control pollutant discharges through equivalent concentration-based limits in lieu of flow-based mass limits for certain industrial categories. EPA established this flexibility because flow-based mass limits can be difficult for the Control Authority to implement and enforce.

Document Name: Pretreatment Streamlining Rule - Fact Sheet 10 - General Control Mechanisms Option (PDF)

Document Name:
Estimating Users of Water Resources: Springfield–Greene County
Data Collection Plan (PDF)
Description/Summary:
One of five integrated planning case study reports. "As part of the Springfield–Greene County effort, EPA investigated  data on water resource users within and downstream of the city and county. After compiling existing data, the EPA project team identified data gaps and developed recommended methods for collecting additional data to address
these gaps. This data collection plan provides next steps for the project partners as well as ideas for other communities on how to collect water resource user data to help support an integrated planning process."

Document Name: Estimating the Value of Water Resources: A Literature Review (PDF)
Description/Summary: -One of five integrated planning case study reports. Springfield, Missouri project partners "needed to estimate the value of their water resources. EPA supported this valuation process by conducting a literature review of relevant studies that examined how similar communities estimated their water resource value. The project partners’ methodology and the EPA literature review results are described."

Description/Summary: Addresses questions raised on WET test method variability and satisfies requirement of 7/1998 settlement agreement with litigants for the Western Coalition of Arid States (WestCAS) and Edison Electric Institute et al. Identifies potential sources of variance associated with WET testing, discusses how to minimize it, and describes how to address it in the NPDES permitting program. Cites Agency and external research, particularly technical information supporting efforts to minimize WET test result variability.

Document Name: Manual for the Evaluation of Laboratories Performing Aquatic Toxicity Tests (PDF)
Description/Summary: This EPA guidance manual provides standardized procedures for conducting on-site audits and evaluations of laboratories performing toxicity tests of effluents and surface waters under the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) compliance monitoring program. This laboratory audit manual (for both freshwater and marine toxicity testing and including the culturing of the test species) was developed to support NPDES inspectors in performing Compliance Evaluation Inspections (CEI) and the Performance Audit Inspections (PAI) consistent with EPA’s NPDES Compliance Inspection Manual.

Document Name: Marine Toxicity Identification Evaluation (TIE) Phase I Guidance Document (PDF)

Document Name: Fact Sheet: Ambient Water Quality Criteria to Address Nutrient Pollution in Lakes and Reservoirs (pdf)
Description/Summary: EPA has published final recommended ambient water quality criteria to address nutrient pollution in lakes and reservoirs under Section 304(a) of the Clean Water Act (CWA). These criteria serve as an important resource in EPA’s ongoing efforts to support states and authorized tribes in developing and adopting numeric nutrient criteria into their water quality standards to protect public health and aquatic life from the adverse effects of nutrient pollution in surface waters, including harmful algal blooms.

Document Name: Ambient Water Quality Criteria to Address Nutrient Pollution in Lakes and Reservoirs (pdf)
Description/Summary: In this document, EPA describes analyses of these new data and provides models from which numeric nutrient criteria can be derived. The criterion models replace the recommended numeric nutrient criteria of 2000 and 2001 and are provided in accordance with the provisions of Section 304(a) of the Clean Water Act (CWA) (Title 33 of the United States Code [U.S.C.] § 1314(a)) for EPA to revise ambient water quality criteria from time to time to reflect the latest scientific knowledge.

Document Name: Addressing Contamination of Drinking Water Distribution Systems from Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) After Wildfires (pdf)

Document Name: National Coordination on EPA Clean Water Act Section 303(d) Actions (pdf)
Description/Summary: The purpose of this memorandum is to describe the process and principles for coordination between EPA Regions and Headquarters (HQ) on Clean Water Act (CWA) Section 303(d) lists (CWA 303(d) lists) and Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDLs) submitted by a state, territory, or authorized tribe (herein referred to as a state). Document Name: Implementation of the District of Columbia and the U.S. Territories Clean Water and Drinking Water Allocations of the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law (pdf)
Description/Summary: This memorandum provides information and guidelines on how EPA will award and administer allocations appropriated to the State and Tribal Assistance Grants (STAG) account in BIL to DC and the Territories, including American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI), Guam, and the U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI). The funds are awarded and administered by EPA Regions 2, 3, and 9 with oversight by EPA Headquarters. The BIL funding is subject to all applicable requirements of the existing Clean Water Act (CWA), Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA), Omnibus Territories Act (OTA), and federal grant regulations.

Document Name: Description of Updates Made to the Lake Criterion Models (pdf)
Description/Summary: The 2017 National Lakes Assessment data were added to the data used to estimate national nutrient criterion models. The larger data set provided an opportunity to explore the effects of variables that might modify stressor-response relationships. Based on these analyses, minor changes were implemented in each of the criterion models.

Document Name: 2022-2032 Vision for the Clean Water Act Section 303(d) Program (pdf)
Description/Summary:
Announces 2022 Vision Program and advises on implementation. "Planning and prioritization should guide the location and timing of TMDL development, the use of other restoration or protection approaches, and the allocation of resources. Each EPA Region should work closely with your states, territories, and tribes on setting priorities in such settings as Performance Partnership Agreements/Grants. EPA will continue to provide tools, data/information, and technical assistance to states, territories, and tribes on prioritization and other goals of the 2022 Vision. EPA and states, territories, and tribes will also utilize program metrics to
promote accountability and illustrate program progress.

Document Name: Waters that Qualify as “Traditional Navigable Waters” Under Section (a)(1) of the Agencies’ Regulations (pdf)

(Posted December 30, 2022 - however, there have been no substantive changes to the guidance since it was issued on May 30, 2007.)

Document Name: Memorandum to the Field Concerning Issues Related to Implementation of Section 404 of the Clean Water Act (CWA) and the Food Security Act of 1985, as Amended (FSA) (“2022 Ag Memo”) (pdf)
Description/Summary: The purpose of this memo is to minimize duplication of efforts pursuant to the CWA section 404 program and the FSA Wetland Conservation Provisions and to facilitate the agencies’ efforts to ensure that federal wetland programs, including those that identify prior converted cropland, are administered in an efficient and effective manner. The 2022 Ag Memo reflects updated policies from the “Revised Definition of ‘Waters of the United States’” rule. The 2022 Ag Memo rescinds the 2020 Ag Memo.

Document Name: Clean Water Act Financial Capability Assessment Guidance (2024 Revision)  (pdf)
Description/Summary:
The FCA Guidance, intitally released in Feburary 2023 and updated in March 2024, replaces the 1997 Combined Sewer Overflows—Guidance for Financial Capability
Assessment and Schedule Development to evaluate a community’s capability to fund CWA control
measures in both the permitting and enforcement context. The FCA Guidance also supplements the
2014 FCA Framework for Municipal Clean Water Act Requirements and the public sector sections of
1995 Interim Economic Guidance for Water Quality Standards to assist states and authorized tribes in
assessing the degree of economic and social impact of potential WQS decisions.

Document Name: Preamble to the 2023 Rule "Revised Definition of 'Waters of the United States'" (88FR 3004-3142) (pdf)
Description/Summary: Because the Supreme Court in Sackett adopted the Rapanos plurality standard and the 2023 rule preamble discussed the Rapanos plurality standard, the implementation guidance and tools in the 2023 rule preamble that address the regulatory text that was not amended by the conforming rule, including the preamble relevant to the Rapanos plurality standard incorporated in paragraphs (a)(3), (4), and (5) of the amended 2023 rule generally remain relevant to implementing the amended 2023 rule.  However, implementation of continuous surface connection is informed by the 2025 Continuous Surface Connection Guidance.

Document Name: CSO Temporal Recreational Uses or WQS variances based on 40 CFR 131.10(g)(3) (pdf)
Description/Summary: This memorandum provides critical information states could submit to EPA to justify the adoption of a CSO temporal recreation use or a WQS variance for a CSO-impacted waterbody to demonstrate that implementing non-CSO control alternatives would result in a greater environmental benefit, but would be precluded, as a practical matter, if the community were required to implement additional CSO controls. Adopting a temporal recreation use or WQS variance for CSO-impacted waters, when adopted consistent with the regulation, would allow a state and the community to holistically consider, identify, and commit to addressing sources of bacteria other than CSO discharges to continue to improve water quality, provide opportunities for safe recreation and achieve a greater health benefit to the public. These actions will help move the nation’s waters further towards the CWA objectives.

Document Name: Final Water Quality Guidance for the Great Lakes (PDF)
Description/Summary: "The Guidance consists of water quality criteria for 29 pollutants to protect aquatic life, wildlife, and human health, and detailed methodologies to develop criteria for additional pollutants; implementation procedures to develop more consistent, enforceable water quality-based effluent limits in discharge permits, as well as total maximum daily loads of pollutants that can be allowed to reach the Lakes and their tributaries from all sources; and antidegradation policies and procedures. Great Lakes States and Tribes will use the water quality criteria, methodologies, policies, and procedures in the Guidance to establish consistent, enforceable, long-term protection for fish and shellfish in the Great Lakes and their tributaries, as well as for the people and wildlife who consume them."

Document Name: Memorandum of Understanding Implementing for One Federal Decision Under Executive Order 13807 (PDF)
Description/Summary: Federal agencies MOU to establish  cooperative relationship for timely processing of environmental reviews and authorization decisions for proposed major infrastructure projects under the One Federal Decision (OFD) policy established in EO 13807.

Document Name: Webinar Recording: Drinking Water Utilities and Professionals Technical Overview of Final PFAS NPDWR
Description/Summary: April 23, 2024 Drinking Water Utilities and Professionals Technical Overview Webinar on the Final PFAS NPDWR

Document Name: Sample Collection Training for EPA's Fifth Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule (UCMR 5)
Description/Summary: Small public water systems (PWSs) subject to participation in EPA’s Fifth Unregulated Contaminate Monitoring Rule (UCMR 5) will learn how to 1) prepare for and schedule UCMR 5 sampling, 2) collect samples for PFAS and lithium analysis while minimizing cross-contamination, and 3) package and ship the UCMR 5 sampling kit to a laboratory for analysis.

Document Name: Webinar Recording: Primacy Package Training
Description/Summary: EPA held an informational training webinar on November 18, 2024 to provide guidance to primacy agency and EPA regional staff to support the submission of primacy packages.

Document Name: Earthquake Resilience Video - Surviving the Quake
Description/Summary: The animated video Surviving the Quake shows the types of damage that earthquakes can cause to water and wastewater utilities. The video discusses the step-wise process to build earthquake resilience and points to the other EPA tools including the Earthquake Resilience Guide and Earthquake Interactive Maps.

Document Name: FY 1990 Guidance for Reporting and Evaluating POTW Noncompliance with Pretreatment Implementation Requirements (PDF)
Description/Summary: Defines criteria for determining which POTWs should be reported on the Quarterly Noncompliance Report (QNCR) for failure to implement pretreatment requirements and criteria for determining which pretreatment violations by POTWs meet the level of significant noncompliance (SNC).  Establishes timely and appropriate criteria for responding to noncompliance for pretreatment implementation violations.

Document Name: Application and Use of the Regulatory Definition of Significant Noncompliance for Industrial Users (PDF)
Description/Summary: Memo to Regional Water Management Division Directors and Approved Pretreatment State Coordinators regarding the application of the significant noncompliance (SNC) definition.

Document Name: Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations - Final Rulemaking - Q & A (PDF)
Description/Summary: Fact sheet provides questions and answers relating to the 2008 Final CAFO Rule.

Document Name: Managing Manure Nutrients at Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations (PDF)
Description/Summary: Document is "designed to supplement EPA’s previous guidance by providing additional technical information to owners, operators, technical service providers, consultants, and permit authorities on how to carry out EPA’s revised regulatory requirements for NPDES permitting of CAFOs. It also provides information on voluntary technologies and management practices that may both improve the production efficiency of CAFOs and further protect the quality of the nation’s waters."

Document Name: Oversight of SIUs Discharging to POTWs Without Approved Pretreatment Programs (PDF)
Description/Summary: Summary of EPA and State responsibilities and options when acting as Control Authorities over significant industrial users discharging to POTWs without approved pretreatment programs.

Document Name: Guide for Evaluating Capacity, Management, Operation, and Maintenance (CMOM) Programs at Sanitary Sewer Collection Systems (PDF)
Description/Summary: Identifies criteria EPA uses to evaluate a collection system’s management, operation, and maintenance (CMOM) program activities.

Document Name: CMOM Program Self-Assessment Checklist (PDF)
Description/Summary: Screening-level tool that can help utilities evaluate Capacity, Management, Operations, and Maintenance (CMOM) programs and identify general areas of strength and weakness.

Document Name: Storm Water Phase II - Compliance Assistance Guide (PDF)
Description/Summary: Explains applicability of 12/9/1999 storm water regulations.

Document Name: Stormwater Best Management Practice: Concrete Washout (PDF)
Description/Summary: Methods for retaining concrete washout water and solids in leak proof containers, so these materials don’t reach surface or ground waters and for recycling concrete washout water and solids.

Document Name: Long-Term Control Plan-EZ (LTCP-EZ) Template: A Planning Tool for CSO Control in Small Communities (PDF)
Description/Summary: Planning tool for small communities that are required  to develop a LTCP to address CSOs. Provides a framework for organization and completion of a LTCP that builds upon existing controls and leads to the elimination or control of CSOs in accordance with the CSO Control Policy.

Document Name: Combined Sewer Overflows - Guidance for Financial Capability Assessment & Schedule Development (PDF)
Description/Summary: Guidance on use of financial capability and other factors identified in the 1994 CSO Control Policy to negotiate schedules for implementation of CSO controls.

Document Name: Getting the Word Out - The Role of Local Governments in Implementing the NPDES Stormwater Program for Construction Sites (PDF)
Description/Summary: Fact sheet describing problems caused by stormwater runoff, responsibilities of construction site operators, and the role local governments play in working with construction site operators to control stormwater runoff.

Document Name: Clean Water Act Regulation of Mine Tailings (PDF)
Description/Summary: Memo regarding need for 404 permits for two projects in AK.

Document Name: National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) Permitting for Environmental Results Strategy (PDF)
Description/Summary: Presents a coordinated and integrated management system that when fully implemented will produce an NPDES program that is more efficient and focuses on environmental results. This Strategy is an important element in an overall plan to meet the watershed restoration goals established in EPA's Strategic Plan.

Document Name: Protecting Water Quality with Green Infrastructure in EPA Water Permitting & Enforcement Programs (PDF)
Description/Summary: Memo to Regions from Stoner and Giles encouraging use of green infrastructure to manage wet weather, and attaching examples of successful incorporation of green infrastructure approaches into permitting and enforcement actions.

Document Name: Guidance Manual for the Control of Wastes Hauled to Publicly Owned Treatment Works (PDF)
Description/Summary:
Provides information for smaller POTWs, generally those without pretreatment programs, on how to develop and implement hauled waste controls. Discusses collection of information on waste haulers, characterization of hauled waste received, evaluation of potential impacts, and development and implementation of  controls. Includes case studies of successful waste hauler programs and example forms.
- Supersedes prior version?

Document Name: Determining Industrial User Significant Noncompliance - One-Page Summary (PDF)
Description/Summary: Memo to Regional Pretreatment Coordinators regarding the application of the significant noncompliance (SNC) definition.

Document Name: Clarification of CWA 316(b) Requirements for Liquified Natural Gas (LNG) Import Terminals (PDF)
Description/Summary: Memo identifies requirements that apply or could potentially apply to cooling water intake structures at Liquified Natural Gas (LNG) import terminals under CWA Section 316(b).

Document Name: Measurable Goals Guidance for Phase II Small MS4s  (PDF)
Description/Summary: Designed to help small municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) operators comply with the six minimum control measures in Phase II stormwater permitting requirements.

Document Name: Applicability of Effluent Guidelines & Categorical Pretreatment Standards to Biodiesel Manufacturing (PDF)

Description/Summary: Appendices B-D of a how-to guide for evaluating an MS4 stormwater program

Provides the inspector, program manager, designer, and owner with an understanding of common stormwater pond and wetland maintenance problems and possible solutions. Document Name: Pretreatment Streamlining Rule - Fact Sheet 3.0 - Equivalent Mass Limits for Concentration Limits (PDF)
Description/Summary: Describes provision in Pretreatment Streamlining Rule that "allows, in limited circumstances, conditional use of equivalent mass limits in lieu of concentration-based limits to facilitate adoption of water-saving technologies."

Document Name: Pretreatment Streamlining Rule - Fact Sheet 6.0 - Optional Sampling Waiver for Pollutants Not Present (EPA-833-F-08-003) (PDF)
Description/Summary: The Pretreatment Streamlining Rule "finalized changes to the General Pretreatment Regulations that allow approved POTW pretreatment programs, or Control Authorities, to reduce or waive certain monitoring requirements that apply to Industrial User discharges subject to categorical Pretreatment Standards. Such IUs are often referred to as Categorical Industrial Users or CIUs. Under EPA’s revised regulations in States that have adopted these provisions, the CA has the discretion to waive sampling of a pollutant if the CIU demonstrates to the CA’s satisfaction that the pollutant is neither present nor expected to be present in the discharge, or is present only at background levels from intake water without any increase in the pollutant due to the CIU’s activities."

Document Name: Pretreatment Streamlining Rule - Fact Sheet 7.0 - Best Management Practices (EPA-833-F-06-013) (PDF)
Description/Summary: Provisions of the Pretreatment Streamlining Rule clarify that POTWs may use best management practices (BMPs) as an alternative to numeric limits that are developed to protect the POTW, water quality, and sewage sludge. In addition, the rule requires that any applicable BMPs be included in the user’s control mechanism, that self-monitoring reports include BMP compliance information where applicable, and that documentation of compliance information for BMPs be maintained by the POTW and the user.

Document Name: Pretreatment Streamlining Rule - Fact Sheet 2.0 - Required Changes (PDF)
Description/Summary: Describes 13 Pretreatment Streamlining Rule changes that are more stringent than the pre-streamlining provisions in 40 CFR Part 403.

Document Name: Permitting for Environmental Results - Permit Issuance and Priority Permits (PDF)

Document Name:
Watershed-Based National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) Permitting Implementation Guidance:
- Includes 12/17/2003 cover memo  (EPA-843-B-91-113) (PDF)
Description/Summary: Describes EPA's recommended steps and ideas for watershed-based permitting implementation under the NPDES permit program. This approach, aimed at achieving new efficiencies and environmental results, provides a process for considering all stressors within a hydrologically defined drainage basin or other geographic area, rather than addressing individual pollutant sources on a discharge-by-discharge basis.
